loans.name: Zosimo

texts.en:
Zosimo Y. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 61 years old. Zosimo is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Zosimo owns & operates a business venture providing transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating "habal-habal" (motorcycle) transport services. Zosimo is just starting this business.

Zosimo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zosimo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Zosimo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family financially.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Lyne

texts.en:
This is Lyne C., 36, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Jolan C. and together they have two children, one of whom is already in college. By the grace of God, Lyne has managed to support her older child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college--a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Lyne as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Lyne operates a  business buying general merchandise from wholesalers, then selling the items piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other such products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 350 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Lyne dreams of being able to give both her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Virgilia

texts.en:
Virgilia G. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Zone 3, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating one business venture selling charcoal.  Her husband Alberto, who is 70 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have eight children who are 24 to 44 years old. 

Virgilia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Virgilia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 which she intends to use to buy additional stock of charcoal to sell in the market so that she could continue to save up for future improvements and expansion for her business.  Virgilia G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: 

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Aiza

texts.en:
Aiza A. is a single woman who lives in Malocbaloc, Brgy. Agujo, Daanbantayan, Cebu.  She earns her living by operating one business venture:a food vending  business.  Her common-law husband Rody Mondejar, who is 29 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in Aiza's business activities. She has three children who are one to five years old. 

 Aiza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Aiza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 which she intends to use to purchase raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future, education of her children and renovation of their house.  Aiza A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: 

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Mardonkul

texts.ru: Зарифов Мардонкул 36-летний женатый мужчина. Живет в районе Вахдат. Имеет двоих детей. Образование среднее. У себя дома занимается производством деревянных сундуков (национальные сундуки "Сандук"). Он в основном производит и продает сундуки на центральном рынке района. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 6 лет. Целью кредита является закуп древесины.
texts.en: Mardonkul Z.  is a 36-year-old married man.  He lives in Vahdat and has two children.  He has a high school education.   He makes traditional wooden chests, called “sanduk,” at home.  Basically, he makes chests and sells them in the central market. He has been doing this work for more than six years.  He is taking out a loan to buy wood.

loans.use: Buying wood

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria M., 48, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Florentino M. and together they have four children, two of whom are in college. By the grace of God, Gloria has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Gloria operates a frozen food business. She sells on credit spiced hams, native sausages and sweetened and cured meat. Customers have one week to pay it back. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products to expand her  inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Gloria dreams of being able to send her children all the way through college so they get stable job someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie D. T. is a married woman who lives in Malocbaloc, Brgy. Agujo, Daanbantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: Food Vending and buying and selling firewood. Her husband Marcelo, who is 33 years old, works as a fisherman/trisikad driver to earn his living.  They have 3 children who are currently going to school and are between 5 to 9 years old. 

Rosalie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,600, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use as additional funds for her business operations so that she can continue to save up for future home improvements. 

 Rosalie D. T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: working capital for her business

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
Chin R. is a 30-year-old married woman who lives the city of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She earns her living by selling desserts in front of a garment factoR., making an income of approximately $3 per day. She has a life partner in her husband who currently is a motor taxi driver in and around his community. This couple doesn’t have a baby yet. 

Chin R. has been staying with her parents since she was single and until the present. Chin R. is concerned that she and her husband ought to live in their own house, but their personal savings account is insufficient to build a new house. To achieve the goal, Chin R. would like to request some funds to build herself a new house to live in. Chin R. was not available the day of the photo, so her husband is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To build herself a new house to live in

loans.name: B & B Group

texts.en:
Jatu K. is the leader of this group of two entrepreneurs. Jatu was born in Makeni city, about thirty years ago. She is married to a motor-bike mechanic and the couple has five children – three in primary school and two in secondary school. For over fifteen years now, she has been selling gara lappers (i.e., locally dyed cloth).  

This is not the first loan that Jatu and her group member have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of their previous loans, they were able to expand their businesses, made more sales and better profit and consequently improved their living conditions. With this new loan, they will be able to further develop their respective businesses. Jatu is going to used her share of the loan to buy lengths of white cotton cloth, powder, caustic soda, inks, starch, etc. in order to produce a large number of gara cloths to sell.

loans.use: Buy lengths of white cotton cloth, powder, caustic soda, inks, starch, etc.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene S. is a 44-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures:   General Store, Rice Dealer and Hog raising businesses.  She lives in Prk. 5, Brgy. Aguisan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her General Store, Rice Dealer and Hog raising businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 16,000.  Arlene is now borrowing PHP 29,500 so that she  can  purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 27,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Arlene aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.  

About NWTF:  

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Munkhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munkhtsetseg is 33 years old and lives with her 2 children and husband. They all live in a wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband operates a taxi service in the city, and her elder son attends a secondary school, while the younger son goes to kindergarten. She used to work for a clothing factory as a tailor for 13 years, and during those years she gained a lot of experience. Therefore, in 2009 she started her own tailoring business.

 Now she has her regular customers already, and she is getting busy now, because of New Year is coming soon therefore she wants to hire someone to help her with the business. Munkhtsetseg is planning to expand her business. She is requesting 1.000.000 MNT loan to purchase some fabric and a sewing machine.

loans.use: purchase some fabric and a sewing machine

loans.name: Ma Luisa

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Ma. Luisa L., or "Isay" as she is known to her friends, knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Ma. Luisa, 49, reached high school and is married to Bernardino, a civilian guard. Together they are raising five children, of whom two are in high school, two are in college, and the other one already working.  Together, they live in GMA, Cavite, Philippines.

Ma. Luisa presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store, in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap bars to candies and energy drinks to rice. Also, she has an alkaline water making machine with which she adds to the income of the family. Having been at least ten years in business, she knows how to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most importantly, her customers. Monthly she is able to earn an average of Php 10,000.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. She also plans to charge up her alkaline water business so that it will also become profitable. Ma. Luisa plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward more profitability.

Ma. Luisa's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.


*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: purchase of more products for the store

loans.name: Gbampo Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Gbampo” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to invest in their respective businesses. In this way, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Sonie K..  Sonie is aged forty; she was born in Makeni city where she is currently residing together with her husband and five children. Her husband is a retired soldier and three of her children are attending secondary school. For five years now, Sonie has been selling cooked rice. With this loan, she will buy cooking ingredients such as palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), rice, fish, salt, Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste), firewood, etc., wholesale.

loans.use: Buy cooking ingredients such as palm oil, rice, fish, salt, Maggi cubes, firewood, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 35 years old and married to Catherine. They have been blessed with one child who is 10 years old. For the last three years Charles has been practicing horticulture, through which he earns monthly profits of Kshs 7,000.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by staff from Kadet and this is his first loan. He intends to use the loan to buy seedlings, pesticide and fuel for the water pumping machine.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to venture into dairy cattle rearing in the future.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, pesticide and fuel

loans.name: Chogjmoo

texts.en:
Chogjmoo T. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her daughter live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her middle child is currently unemployed and her son attends a local high school. Her older son currently serves in the Mongolian military and went abroad as a peacekeeper. 

Chogjmoo operates a meat trading business in her town. She sells a variety of meats to her customers at a stall in the local market. She started her business in 1993 and has since gained much experience. She says, "I hope that my son will come back to us healthy." She is requesting a 2,200,000 MNT loan to purchase livestock to sell.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy used handbags to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Janepher Khakasa

texts.en:
Janepher Khakasa M. is 39 years old. She is married to Stephen Wafula and a mother of five beautiful children. Janepher lives in Maili Saba in Kitale town, where her business is. She buys clothing materials, makes clothes and later sells the clothes to her customers. Janepher gets a monthly income of eighteen thousand shillings and has been in this business for eight years now. She also has a grocery shop on the side. 

This will be Janepher's second loan from KADET. She will use the loan to purchase a new sewing machine worth fifteen thousand shillings and will use the balance to buy more materials for making clothes. She plans to invest the income she is going to get back into her business so that she can earn more income.

In the future, Janepher hopes to purchase a plot of land, build rental houses, educate her children to the highest level and also raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and materials for making clothes

loans.name: Fidélia D. M.

texts.fr: Âgée de 44 ans, Fidélia est mariée et a 4 enfants à charge. Ses enfants sont tous scolarisés. Elle est dans sa 10ème année d'expérience dans le commerce donc maitrise très bien son activité. Elle commercialise les céréales, les plastiques et les produits alimentaires tels que les sardines, les tomates en boîtes, les boites de nescafé, les cartons de sucres, du lait en poudre ou concentré. Ses clients sont constitués des ménages de la zone et de ses environs. Elle s'approvisionne auprès des grossistes à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin et pour les céréales au moins une fois par semaine dans d'autres marchés du Bénin tels que Houègbo, Glo et Djoda. Dans le souci d'une meilleure satisfaction de sa clientèle, elle a sollicité et obtenu un micro crédit à FINADEV pour bien ravitailler sa boutique en divers produits alimentaires et en céréales. Le revenu supplémentaire généré par le micro crédit lui permettra de faire face aux charges personnelle et familiale. Fidélia est à son 3ème crédit à FINADEV. Elle souhaiterait avoir sa propre maison de distribution de gros des produits alimentaires. Fidélia est la caution solidaire de ZANNOU Victoire avec qui elle est dans la photo. Elle est la responsable du groupe, sur la photo, Fidélia est du côté droit, dans un ensemble multicolore blanc, rouge, jaune et bleu.
texts.en: Âgée de 44 ans, Fidélia est mariée et a 4 enfants à charge. Ses enfants sont tous scolarisés. Elle est dans sa 10ème année d'expérience dans le commerce donc maitrise très bien son activité. Elle commercialise les céréales, les plastiques et les produits alimentaires tels que les sardines, les tomates en boîtes, les boites de nescafé, les cartons de sucres, du lait en poudre ou concentré. Ses clients sont constitués des ménages de la zone et de ses environs. Elle s'approvisionne auprès des grossistes à Tokpa, le plus grand marché du Bénin et pour les céréales au moins une fois par semaine dans d'autres marchés du Bénin tels que Houègbo, Glo et Djoda. Dans le souci d'une meilleure satisfaction de sa clientèle, elle a sollicité et obtenu un micro crédit à FINADEV pour bien ravitailler sa boutique en divers produits alimentaires et en céréales. Le revenu supplémentaire généré par le micro crédit lui permettra de faire face aux charges personnelle et familiale. Fidélia est à son 3ème crédit à FINADEV. Elle souhaiterait avoir sa propre maison de distribution de gros des produits alimentaires. Fidélia est la caution solidaire de ZANNOU Victoire avec qui elle est dans la photo. Elle est la responsable du groupe, sur la photo, Fidélia est du côté droit, dans un ensemble multicolore blanc, rouge, jaune et bleu.

loans.use: To stock her store with various food products to meet her customers' needs.

loans.name: Cho

texts.en:
Cho V. is a hard–working man who makes daily profit by carrying goods in a ferryboat, earning a profit on average of $2.50 per day. His wife works in a private company as an internal staff member and has a fixed salary each month. They are blessed with five children who are all single. Two of them are working in different careers and share their salary to cover the family’s expenses. 

Currently, Cho V.’s wife wishes to start a new business in the ferryboat and sell products such as water, fast food, and plastic items in order to add revenue. Cho V. said that he lacks capital to run the new business. To achieve this purpose, Cho V. will use his loan to buy necessary items such as water, fast food, other products to sell. Cho V. was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy necessary items such as water, fast food, other products to sell

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mr. Yan M. has spent his life cultivating crops in  Pnom Penh City. This is a skill he learned from his grandparents when he was young. Mr. Yan M. is now married and has six children; five are single and the other one is married. Three of them are employed as  workers in a factory and have a formal salary. His wife works in the farm fields frequently alongside him. 

Growing crops is an annual endeavor with which he has had great success. Mr. Yan M. is able to plant the crops at least twice a year, using both rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall will be good for his crop, however, Mr. Yan M. doesn’t have capital yet to use on his farm. So, Mr. Yan M. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizer, a pump, and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, a pump, and seeds for planting

loans.name: Amadou

texts.fr:
Né vers 1959 à SAN, préfecture du même nom, région de Ségou, Amadou K. n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, alors il embrassa tôt les activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce de céréales avec son père. Il est marié à une épouse et  père de 8 enfants. Il vit chez lui même dans le quartier DALLAN de la préfecture de San.  
Il est dans le domaine du commerce de céréales depuis maintenant 30 ans, et l’exerce actuellement pour lui même au grand marché  de San depuis 20 ans. Il est très sollicité lors  des foires hebdomadaires de San  ville et environnants.  
Pour augmenter la taille de son activité, il décida de faire recours à l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a trois ans.  Il est à son 3ème  prêt individuel. Monsieur Amadou K. compte acheter, 4 tonnes de riz décortiqués, 2 tonnes de petits mils, 3,5 tonnes de mils et 2 tonnes de haricot. Il s’approvisionnait  auprès des commerçants grossistes de San, mais avec l’augmentation du fonds de commerce, il compte aller jusque chez les producteurs pour  s’approvisionner. Il vend tous les jours au grand marché de San et dans les foires hebdomadaires à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes, à crédit et au comptant. 
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 130 000FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser le prêt, payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, acheter la nourriture et investir le reste dans d’autres activités de revenus .
Il ambitionne solliciter un financement plus important qui pourra lui permettre d’agrandir son activité et par conséquent augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour qu’il puisse améliorer sa condition de vie.
texts.en:
Born around 1959, in the town and prefecture of San, Ségou region, Amadou K. did not have the opportunity to go to school, so early on, he became involved in revenue-producing activities, in particular, selling cereal with his father. 

He is married and the father of eight children. He lives in his own house in the Dallan neighborhood, San prefecture. He has been in the buisness of selling cereal for 30 years now, and he has been working for himself at the grand market of San for 20 years. Amadou is very much in demand during the weekly fairs in San and the surrounding area. 

To increase his business, he decided to turn to micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. He is on his third personal loan. Mr. Amadou K. plans to buy 4 tons of husked rice, 2 tons of pearl millet, 3.5 tons of millet and 2 tons of beans. He obtains his supplies from the wholesalers in San, but with this increase in his capital, he plans to buy directly from the producers. 

He sells everyday at the  grand market in San and at the weekly fairs to customers who are both men and women, on credit  or in cash. He hopes to make a monthly profit of 130,000 CFA francs which he plans to use to repay the loan, pay for his children's schooling, buy food and and invest the rest in other income-producing activities. His goal is to ask for a bigger loan which will allow him to expand his business, increase his turnover and improve his quality of life.

loans.use: To buy cereal

loans.name: Bourema

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bourema D., âgé de 45 ans, marié à une femme et père de 3 enfants, vit dans le quartier Médine de la ville de San (région de Ségou) .
L’activité principale de Monsieur Bourema est l’agriculture à savoir l’achat et la vente de jeunes plants (arbres fruitiers et non fruitiers) à San. 
Monsieur Bourema D. confectionne d’abord des pépinières et achète ensuite à Sikasso auprès des pépiniéristes et planteurs,  des plantes jeunes de : (Manguiers, Nîmes , Caïcédras, Cocos etc.)  Il fait cette activité il y’a plus de 7 ans. Il est très sollicité dans son activité.
Dans le souci de satisfaire ses clients qui deviennent de plus en plus nombreux, Bourema à intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son troisième cycle de prêt individuel et les deux précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Il envisage acheter 300 pieds de mangue, 100 pieds de Nîmes et plusieurs autres plantes sur commandes.  
Le bénéfice escompté par mois est de 100 000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des échéances, subvenir au besoin de sa famille  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Bourema D. is a 45-year-old married man and father of three children. He lives in the Medina district of the city of San (region of Ségou).

His main activity is agriculture, more specifically the purchase and sale of seedlings (fruit and non-fruit trees) in San. First, Mr. D. makes the nursery beds. Then, in Sikasso, he purchases seedlings from nurserymen and planters, including Mango trees, Nîmes trees, Caïcédras trees, Coco trees, etc.).  He has been in this business for over seven years and is in very high demand.

In order to satisfy his growing clientele, Bourema joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is his third individual loan cycle. The two previous loans have been fully repaid.

He plans to buy 300 mango seedlings, 100 Nîmes seedlings, and several other plants on order.

He expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan and provide for his family, the remainder to be invested in his business.

loans.use: Purchase of seedlings

loans.name: Sou

texts.en:
Sou S. is a 62-year-old man, married to Some Sou, age 58. This older couple live with three children and earn a living by planting various crops on their own farmland. Sou S. currently plants various vegetables, which he will harvest and sell when they are mature. 

Recently, his crop is not growing well because it is ravaged by insect and weeds. Because of that obstacle, Sou S. has decided to seek a loan to buy insecticide, which he will use to protect his vegetables, and farm supplies to use on his field.

loans.use: To buy insecticide, which he will use to protect his vegetables, other farm supplies to use on his field

loans.name: Diarha

texts.fr:
Né le 27-avril 1959 à  SAN, Diarha K. n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, elle a alors embrassé très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus. Elle est mariée et mère de  6 enfants. Elle vit chez son époux dans le quartier Dabani de la préfecture de San.  
Elle excelle dans l’achat et la vente de poissons frais et fumé. Elle a appris cette activité  auprès de son mari il y a plus de 8 ans et l’exerce actuellement pour elle même au grand marché  de San depuis 5 ans.  Elle est très sollicitée lors  des foires hebdomadaires de San  ville et environnants.  
Afin de diversifier son activité, elle décida de faire recours à l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 4 ans, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel. 
Madame Diarha  Keïta  compte acheter 30 paniers de poisson frais et 40 cartons de poisson fumé pour sa vente dans les différents marchés hebdomadaires et autres. Elle s’approvisionne au bord du fleuve avec les pêcheurs et   revend tous les jours au grand marché de San et dans les foires hebdomadaires à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes à crédit et au comptant. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt, payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, venir en aide à son époux et investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenus .
texts.en:
Born on April 27, 1959 in San, Ms. Diarha K. did not have the chance to attend school.   She therefore soon embraced revenue-generating work.  She is married, the mother of six children, and lives with her husband in the Dabani district in San prefecture.   She excels in buying and selling fresh and smoked fish.  She learned this business from her husband over eight years ago and has been operating it for herself at the grand market of San for five years now.  She is in high demand during weekly fairs in and around the city of San.

In order to diversify her business, Diarha decided to turn to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago.  She is now on her third individual loan.  She plans on buying 30 baskets of fresh fish and 40 boxes of smoked fish to sell at the different weekly markets and elsewhere.  She acquires her goods at the riverside from fisherfolk.  Accepting cash or credit, she resells her goods every day to a customer base composed of men and women at the grand market of San and at weekly fairs.  

She plans on making a monthly profit of 70,000 francs CFA that she envisions using to make the loan payments, to cover the schooling costs for her children, to help out her husband, and to invest the rest in other revenue-generating businesses.

loans.use: Achat  de poissons

loans.name: Peace And Unity Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “Peace and Unity” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Cecilia K. is the leader of this group. The forty-two-year-old is married to an agric instructor and they have five children, three attending primary school and one in college. Cecilia has been a businesswoman for twenty-three years now; she sells ready-to-wear-clothes, “Bamako cloth” and lace cloth. She also sells market food such as rice and palm oil.  With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items wholesale to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy clothes, rice and palm oil in large quantity for sale

loans.name: Dossolo

texts.fr:
Né vers 1971  à  SAN, préfecture du même nom, Monsieur Dossolo M. n’a pas pu faire de brillantes études (car abandonna l’école en classe de 8ème année  fondamentale : système éducatif Malien), alors il s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus c'est-à-dire le commerce de céréales. Il est marié à deux épouses et est père de 5 enfants. Il vit chez lui même à Sienso de la préfecture de San.  
Il excelle dans la vente de céréales  qu’ il a appris  auprès de son père il y a une vingtaine d’année. Il l’exerce actuellement pour lui même à Sienso.  Il est très sollicité   dans les foires hebdomadaire de San  ville et environnants.  
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de son activité, il décida de faire recours à l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans.  Il est à son deuxième prêt  individuel. 
Monsieur Dossolo  compte acheter, 1 tonne de riz paddy, 2 tonnes de petits mils et 0,5 tonnes de mils. Il s’approvisionne auprès des commerçants  grossistes de Sienso, mais avec l’augmentation du fonds de commerce, il compte aller jusque chez les cultivateurs pour  s’approvisionner. Il vend tous les jours  à Sienso au bord du goudron, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes à crédit et au comptant. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000 FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt,  utiliser le reste pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, acheter la nourriture et investir le reste dans d’autres activités  génératrices de revenus .
Il ambitionne augmenter son prochain prêt afin d’améliorer sa condition de vie.
texts.en:
Born around 1971 in San, in the prefecture of San, Mr. Dossolo M. did not have a chance to excel  in academic studies (having left school in 8th grade of general studies, as per Mali educational system), and so he turned his attention to making a living, more specifically selling cereals. He has two wives and is the father of five children. He lives in his own home in Sienso, in the San prefecture. He masters the cereals business, having learned it from his father some twenty years ago. He has his own business in Sienso. He is very much in demand at the weekly markets of the town of San and nearby areas. 

With the goal of expanding his business, two years ago he decided to seek assistance from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his second individual loan.

Mr. Dossolo plans to purchase 1 ton of rice paddy, 2 tons of small millet and 0.5 tons of millet. He buys his stock form wholesalers of Sienso, but with the increased working capital he plans to go directly to farmers to stock up. He sells in Sienso everyday,  next to the asphalted road, to a client base composed of women and men, on credit and for cash. He expects to achieve a monthly income of 40,000 West African Francs, which he plans to use for repaying the loan, with the rest used to cover school fees of his children and food. The rest will be reinvested in his business. He has his sights set on increasing his next loan in order to improve his life conditions.

loans.use: Achat  de céréales

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ibrahim M.  est l’un des clients de Soro Yiriwaso, qui  est marié et père de 4 enfants. Ibrahim a 35 ans et vit à Sienso, un des quartiers périphériques de San (région de Ségou)
L’activité principale de Monsieur Ibrahim est l’achat et la vente des téléphones portables ainsi que des cartes de recharges, des batteries pour téléphones, des façades de téléphones et autres accessoires pour téléphones. Il est très sollicité dans son activité.
Dans le souci de satisfaire ses clients qui deviennent de plus en plus nombreux  Ibrahim intègre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son deuxième cycle de prêt individuel  et le premier a été correctement remboursé. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako tous les mois et compte acheter avec ce nouveau prêt, 200 portables  de toutes séries confondues, 100 batteries et plusieurs  paquets d’accessoires.  Monsieur Ibrahim espère réaliser par mois  50 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des échéances, subvenir au besoin de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahim M. is a client of Soro Yiriwaso, married and the father of four. Ibrahim is 35 years old and lives in Sienso, a peripheral district of San (Ségou Region). His main line of business is purchase and resale of mobile phone as well as phone recharge cards, batteries, covers, and other mobile accessories.  His business is very much in demand. In order to better meet the needs of his clients, whose numbers keep growing, Ibrahim joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and is now on his second individual loan, having duly repaid his first loan.

Ibrahim stocks up in Bamako once a month and plans to use this new loan to purchase 200 mobile phones of all kinds of different brands and models, 100 batteries and several packs of accessories. He hopes to earn 50,000 West African francs per month, which will be used to repay his loan and provide for his family’s needs, with the rest reinvested in his business

loans.use: Purchasing mobile phones and accessories

loans.name: Talapsu Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Talapsu” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Aminata K.. Aminata is age thirty; she was born in Makeni city where she is currently residing together with her husband and three children. Her husband is a lecturer and two of her children are attending primary and secondary schools. Aminata has been a businesswoman for more than ten years now, she sells shoes, shirts, jeans, and mobile phones. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy shoes, shirts, jeans, and mobile phones in large quantity to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.en:
A. Dilshod lives in Gonchi, a region in Northern Tajikistan. He is 29 years old, married with two children. Dilshod is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling cows at the local market. His wife helps him with the business. Once every 2-3 months he purchases young animals from local villagers and raises them over an 8-9 month period and later sells the adult cows to local butchers. Today Dilshod is thinking about expanding his business, as his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase young cattle. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 6000 Somoni.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle

loans.name: Sohib

texts.en:
A. Sohib is 22 years old. He is married and has one little child. For more than 5 years Sohib has been running a joiner’s shop manufacturing wooden doors and window frames. The business of Sohib is quite profitable and generates a stable income allowing him to support his family and improve their living conditions. 

Sohib is respected as a good master in his neighborhood. Now he needs to purchase input materials for his manufacturing shop. With this purpose he requests 6000 Somoni as his third loan loan. Sohib promises to repay his loan in a timely manner and thanks everyone for their support.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of necessary materials for his manufacturing needs

loans.name: Bekzod

texts.en:
The business activity from which Bekzod makes a living is the raising livestock. He started this business three years ago with a small number of livestock, but as his business has developed, he has acquired greater quantities of animals for eventual sale and use of their derivatives. According to Bekzod, he works very hard so that he can support his family. For that reason, he is always looking for a way to improve the living conditions of his family. Currently Bekzod needs a loan of $3000 USD in order to purchase more cattle to later resell after raising them. This will allow him to fully meet the needs of his family.

loans.use: Purchasing calves to develop his business

loans.name: Kankalay Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the Kankalay group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Waterloo, a small town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 1,000,000 SLL for each from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, increase their profits, and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Serreh K..  Born in Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital, she is 45 years old, married, and has six children, all of whom attend school.  Her husband is a soldier. 

Serreh sells foodstuffs, including gari (fast food made out of cassava roots), palm oil, rice, ground nuts, and vegetable oil. She has been a businesswoman for 25 years. With her share of the loan, she will buy three bags of gari, two bags of rice, 25 gallons of palm oil, and two bags of ground nuts to add to her business.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs, such as gari, palm oil, rice, ground nuts, and vegetable oil

loans.name: Uktam

texts.en:
For the past four years, Uktam K. has worked in agriculture, raising cattle. With the income earned from this endeavor, he can cover his household expenses. Uktam's cattle require vaccinations against various sicknesses that affect that type of livestock. For Uktam, it is very important to work raising his animals, which is why he is currently seeking a loan in order to purchase additional cattle. The additional cattle will help his family generate additional income. Uktam appreciates your support for his project.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Phillip K. Rono is a 42-year-old farmer. He is married with five children between 7 and 18 years of age. He is a small-scale Maize farmer and also keeps poultry.

Phillip has been in business for the last 13 years. From this business he gets a profit of Kshs 2,000 a month. He has borrowed a third loan of Kshs 35,000, of which he intends to use Kshs 5,000 to buy seeds, Kshs 8,000 for fertilizer, Kshs 12,000 for wages, Kshs 5,000 for transport and Kshs 5,000 for other overhead costs.
   
Phillip anticipates using his profits to pay school fees for his children and expand his business. His dream is to educate his children, improve their living standard through better provision of food and clothing, and also expand his business.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers and pay for wages, transport, and other overhead costs

loans.name: Kahunge Catholic Catechist Association Group

texts.en: Julius is a 41-year-old married man blessed with seven children and living in his own house in Kanwenge, Uganda. The responsibility to take care of the family lies on his shoulders and his dream is to educate his children and own a permanent house. He has been a farmer for over 20 years, starting from a subsistence farmer to a commercial one supplying the county. However, he is faced with price fluctuation challenges and this is a great set back. His business plan is to farm on a large scale and be able to export his produce. Julius needs the loan to buy seedlings for planting this season.

loans.use: To buy seedlings for planting

loans.name: Abdumajid

texts.en:
M. Abdumajid is 33 years old. He is married with two children. From the time he was young, Abdumajid was learning to work in the small business of cattle breeding. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice, and seeing his family progressing more and more. His hope is to continue growing and improving his business to offer a better future for his children, and see them as professional, ethical and hardworking. For this reason Abdumajid is asking for a loan of $1000 USD. He wants this loan to buy additional livestock and is sincerely thankful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Alisher

texts.en:
O. Alisher is a loving and self-sacrificing father. Ever since he was young, Alisher has been around people raising animals, and thanks to this knowledge, he dedicates himself to raising and selling cattle, work that he learned from his humble parents. With experience gained over time in the purchase and sales of cattle, he has been able to bring stability to his family. The desire that Alisher harbors in his heart is to increase his capital and invest in acquiring more animals. By doing this, he can create more income for his family. Above all, he hopes to offer a better quality of life for his beloved children, who always support him unconditionally in his daily work. Alisher requests 12,500 TJS. Let’s get together behind the request of this devoted father to help him keep bringing stability and security to the members of his family.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Justine

texts.en: Justine is a forty-five-year old married female with four children owning a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been in a bar and lodging business for ten years.  She started with initial capital of 100.000 Uganda shillings and expanded to 3,000,000 Uganda shillings. Her vision is to expand the business and to educate her children.  Justine intends to use the loan to buy tables and seats for her bar.

loans.use: Buying seats,tables for her bar

loans.name: Badriddin

texts.en:
Badriddin R. is 35 years old. He is married with three children. Badriddin has been a farmer for the last 15 years. Farming is a passion for him. He practices both dairy farming and mixed crop farming. Badriddin says he has chosen farming as a career because the produce reaped from his farm has a ready market. His challenge at the moment is that he is not fully utilizing all his land.  This is because he used up all his proceeds form the last harvest to pay his children's school fees and was not able to buy the seeds and fertilizers needed to plant all of his land. Badriddin is requesting a loan of 10 000 Somoni to be able to purchase the resources needed for the next planting season. He will purchase assorted seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Hamrokul

texts.en:
Hamrokul Y. is 54 years old. He is married and has 3 children. His wife is a housekeeper. 
Hamrokul's business is the main source of income for his family. Hamrokul has provided transportation services for the last 20 years. Each day he transports different goods on his lorry for his clients. Hamrokul needs to make major repairs to his lorry in order to provide better service to his clients.  He raises cattle with his elder son. He also he wants to buy young cattle.

loans.use: Purchasing of spare parts for the lorry and young cattle.

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude B. lives in the Kawala neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 8 children. All of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (a brother's son ).     Gertrude has a retail shop.  She has been in this business for less than one year.  She works 7 days of every week.  Gertrude has requested a loan of 700000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO.  She will use it to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil.  She also generates additional income by renting rooms.
The main business challenges for Gertrude include defaulters and seasonality challenges.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop and build more rental rooms .   Gertrude lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication .

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar,cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil

loans.name: Mehrullo

texts.en:
Mehrullo, a farmer, lives with his family, comprised of his wife, two children and parents. His father helps him in the care of their land. In the past they have had problems in harvesting, forcing them to sell their crop in advance, thereby resulting in reduced earnings. Mehrullo has subsequently gained much business experience and now his crop is one of the most demanded at the market. Because his field is infertile, he has decided to request a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants to support the field and make his crop more productive.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Abdunabi

texts.en:
Abdunabi R., a 38-year-old married father of three children, has sold furniture for many years. Having become a real expert in the process, he knows all about the quality of various producers. Abdunabi is polite with his clients and ready to offer the furniture that will meet any taste and income level. The business is stable and generates an income sufficient to support the needs of his family.

He is now requesting a loan of 13000 Somoni to purchase new items of furniture to sell. Abdunabi sincerely thanks everyone for their support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new items of furniture for selling

loans.name: Alisalam

texts.en:
Alisalam A. is a married 32-year-old man. He lives with his family in Mahammadali village in the Imishli region. He is a father to one son and one daughter. In 2007 he started his own poultry business to support his large, six-person family. It is the only source of income for his family.

This is the first loan Alisalam received from Aqroinvest and KIVA. He used the 1000 AZN loan to buy more chickens. After repaying this loan Alisalam plans to take out another loan to build a new hen coop.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Reuben C.

texts.en:
Reuben C. K. is 50 years old, married to Margaret Chepkonga, and they have eight children aged between 26 and 10 years old. 
  
Reuben runs butchery at Kapkiamo trading centre few kilometers from Kabarnet town. He has been in this business for almost 17 years, and his average monthly profit from the business is Kshs 4,000. He has applied for his third loan of Kshs.20,000 from KADET, after successfully paying back the previous loans. He intends to use the loan to purchase goats for slaughter to meet the demand during the  festive season. 
  
He anticipates using his profits to start maize and horticulture farming in order to increase his income. His hopes and dreams are to have a big business and give his children the best education.

loans.use: To purchase  animals for slaughter

loans.name: Lumiere Group

texts.fr: Kalimutma F. est  entrepreneur, âgée de 35 ans, mariée, mère de 7 enfants. Tous ses enfants étudient sauf le cadet. Son mari est  cultivateur.  Elle vend des cannes à sucre.  Elle  commença son business  avec  le crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Elle installe ses produits  à son domicile(vente en  gros et détail). Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec 2 tonnes de canne à sucre en provenance du territoire de Rutshuru. En plus, elle ambitionne acheter une parcelle pour sa famille et voir ses enfants finir les études. La cliente Kalimutma F. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe lumière est constitué de 23 membres.
texts.en: Kalimutma F. is an entrepreneur.  She is 35 years old, married, and the mother of 7 children.  All of her children are in school except the youngest.  Her husband is a farmer.  She sells cane sugar.  She began her business with a loan of $50 from the IMF Hekima.  She sets up her products in her home (selling in bulk and at retail).  This new loan will allow her to stock up with two tons of cane sugar from the territory of Rutshuru.  Moreover, she hopes to buy a parcel for her family and to see her children finish their studies.  The client Kalimutma F. thanks Hekima for its work to help the impoverished who are excluded by classic banks.  The Lumière group is made up of 23 members.

loans.use: acheter 2 tonnes de canne à sucre

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Paradizo Group

texts.fr: Shamamba K. est entrepreneur, âgée de 32 ans, femme vivant seule, mère de 4 enfants.  Elle vend des habits usagers (friperie). Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre, initiée par sa mère. Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ en 2008. Elle installe ses produits  au petit marché sectoriel du quartier TMK. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  1 ballon de vêtements (friperie).  En plus, elle ambitionne devenir commerçante grossiste des friperies. La cliente Shamamba K. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Paradizo est constitué de 27 membres.
texts.en: Shamamba K. is an entrepreneur.  She is 32 years old, a single woman, and the mother of 4 children.  She sells used clothing (second-hand).  She began her business with her own funds, given by her mother.  Later on, she received a loan for $50 from IMF Hemika in 2008.  She sets up her products in the small sectoral market of the neighborhood TMK.  This new loan should allow her to stock up with one ball of clothing (second-hand).  Moreover, she hopes to become a wholesaler of second-hand clothing.  The client Shamamba K. thanks Hekima for its work to help the impoverished who are excluded by classic banks.  The group Paradizo is made up of 27 members.

loans.use: To buy a ball of clothes (second-hand)

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Upendo Kahembe Group

texts.fr: Ngenda R. est entrepreneur, âgée de41 ans, mariée, mère de 7 enfants. Son époux vend des Fanta.  Elle aussi, vend des produits vivriers notamment  oignons et aies.  Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre reçu de son époux, il ya 14 ans. Plus tard, elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Elle installe ses produits dans un dépôt agricole sur le long de la route vers l’aéroport international de Goma. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  les 2 sacs d’aies et 400 kg d’oignons. En plus, elle ambitionne augmenter son compte épargne, scolariser confortablement ses enfants, et construire une maison pour sa famille. La cliente Ngenda R. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Ce groupe Upendo kahambe a 13 membres.
texts.en:
Ngenda R. is an entrepreneur, 41 years old, married and the mother of seven children. Her husband sells Fanta. She sells produce, largely onions and garlic. She started her business 14 years ago with her own funds, which she received from her husband. Later, she received a $50 loan from the microfinance institution Hekima. 

She sells her products from a warehouse on a farm along the road to the international airport of Goma. This new loan will be used to purchase two bags of garlic and 400 kg of onions. In addition, she hopes to grow her savings account, well-school her children, and build a house for her family. 

This client, Ngenda R., thanks Hekima for its actions helping the poor people excluded from traditional banks. The group Upendo Kahamba has 13 members.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of garlic and 400 kg of onions

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Waeni

texts.en:
Waeni K. is 27 years old and married to John. They have four children and her spouse contributes to the family income. She has a motor bike transport business which she has been running for about three years now with an income of  Kshs.25,000 per month. 

She is taking her second loan from KADET LTD after successfully repaying the previous loans well and on time. She will use the loan to buy an extra motor bike to meet clients needs. She hopes to educate her children to the highest level and improve their living standard.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, sardines, and drinks

loans.name: Shaiq

texts.en:
Shaiq A. is a 46-year-old family man. He is father to one son and two daughters who attend school. Shaiq lives with his family in the Marzali village, Imishli region. He is a hard-working man who makes a living breeding cattle and selling meat and dairy. He has been involved in this business since 2005 and his father helps him in it. 

This is Shaiq’s second loan from Aqroinvest. He successfully repaid his first loan. Shaiq used the loan of 1000 AZN to buy one cow. Now he has two cows but after repaying this loan he would like to take out another loan to buy four more cows. Shaiq is very thankful to Aqroinvest and KIVA for the opportunity to expand his business so his family can make a better living.

loans.use: to buy one cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and cartons of laundry soap

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 39 years old and married to Rosemary who sells cloth.They have been blessed with two children aged 15 and 10 years. He has been a carpenter for the last 10 years managing a profit of Ksh 20,000/= monthly. He is more likely to succeed because his wife contributes to meeting their expenses, hence paving the way for his growth.

The loan will be used to purchase timber. He plans to use the anticipated profits to purchase a grooving machine and grow his business further. This is his third loan with Kadet after successfully repaying the previous loans. He dreams of owning a workshop that will produce quality furniture.

loans.use: Timber

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, gallons of oil, beans, tomatoes, seasoning, bitter balls, etc.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 33-year-old, married to Cecilia who owns a green grocery. They have been blessed with one child aged four years. Moses has been in the charcoal and charcoal stoves business for the last 14 years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs.10,000.

Moses was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs.30,000, which he plans to spend as follows: buy charcoal worth Kshs.10,000 and charcoal stoves costing Kshs.20,000

His future dream is to become a charcoal supplier to small restaurants.

loans.use: charcoal stoves and charcoal to stock

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 34 years old and married to George, 40, who is also a farmer. They  have three children. She has been in the farming business for eight years and earns Ksh 5,000 monthly.

Esther has no history with any other micro-finance institution, and she has applied for a loan of Kshs.10,000 from KADET,planning to buy farm inputs, that is, seeds and fertilizer.

Kiambu town is an area with high agricultural potential, serving a large population. With combined efforts from her husband, she is more likely to thrive than most. She plans to use the anticipated profits to lease another plot of land to increase  their income. Her dreams and hopes are to buy her own land.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs: seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en: Gorret N. lives in the Namungoona neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. Gorret has a retail shop. She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days out of every week. Gorret has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and cooking oil. The main business challenges for Gorret are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a wholesale shop. Gorret lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses are rent, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 41-year-old lady married to Patrick who is also a farmer. They have four children aged 18,15,11 and six years. She has been in horticulture and dairy farming for the last 10 years earning a monthly income of Kshs 12,000. 

With the assistance of her husband she is most likely to succeed because he is in a position to contribute to their daily expenses hence leaving room for her business growth. She plans to use the loan to lease an extra acre of land so as to increase her production which will result in income increase. She plans to use the anticipated profits to purchase a dairy cow. This is her second loan with Kadet after successfully repaying her  previous loan.

loans.use: Lease an extra acre of land to increase her farm output and purchase an extra cow.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a young man, aged 24 years, married to Tabitha who is expecting their first born. He has been in the pig-keeping business for the last year managing to earn a monthly income of Ksh 8,000. The fact that he successfully repaid his previous two loans from Kadet is a clear indication that he is doing well.

He plans to use the loan to purchase six piglets amounting to 10,000/= and the rest 10, 000 will be used to buy animal feeds. He plans to use the expected profits to uplift the living standards of his family and give proper care to his family. He dreams of becoming a large-scale farmer in pig-keeping.

loans.use: Purchase pigs worth Kshs 10,000

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more red oil.

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en: Gertrude N. lives in the Namungoona neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married, and has two children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (sister and brother). Gertrude has a business selling milk. She has been in this business for eight years, and she works seven days out of every week. Gertrude sells her products door-to-door. Gertrude has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy to buy more jerry cans of milk. She also generates additional income through hiring of motorcycles. The main business challenges for Gertrude are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on wholesale only. Gertrude lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses are rent, school fees, and food.

loans.use: To buy more jerry cans of milk

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has seven children, all of whom are in school. Betty has a business running a food stall. She has been in this business for six years, and she works seven days out of every week. Betty sells her products from home, on a retail basis. Betty has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy baskets of fish, eggplants, sugar cane, tomatoes, and oranges. The main business challenges for Betty are transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to build her own house.   Betty lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees, and food.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish, eggplants, tomatoes, and oranges.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a single lady and has a daughter who is 15 years old. She has been running a boutique for a year which earns her a monthly income of Ksh 15,000. Westlands being a high class area near the city center, she is most likely to get many clients that will make her business succeed.  

She was introduced to Kadet by a friend who has also benefited and this is her first loan through KADET, with which she intends to buy more clothes and bags for sale during the festive season. She plans to use the anticipated profits to grow her business even further and give her daughter a good education.

loans.use: Purchase stock for a boutique

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clay products to resell

loans.name: Fuerza Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Fuerza inicia su cuarto ciclo con 15 socias, las cuales tiene diversos negocios. Gloria socia del Banco comunal tiene 40 años, es casada, y tiene 2 hijos D. 17 y 12 años.
Gloria se dedica a la compra y venta D. cochinilla y tara. Aprendió D. éste negocio por su hermana, ella viaja a las ferias D. Cangallo y Colca, ahí compra la cochinilla y tara y lo lleva a su casa, lo hace secar y lo venD. a los acopiadores.
Le gusta las reuniones D. su Banco Comunal porque aprenD. mucho D. las capacitaciones que recibe D. su promotora en los temas D. negocios, familia, matrimonio.
El sueño D. gloria es poder juntar un capital y poder comprarse una máquina D. tejer para elaborar chompas y venderlos.
texts.en:
The 'Fuerza' (Strength) community bank is starting its fourth loan cycle with 15 members who have different businesses.  Gloria is one of the bank's members.  She is 40 years old, married, and has two children aged 17 and 12.  Gloria buys and sells 'tara' (a native plant used for tanning leather) and cochineal (an insect used to make natural dye).  She learned this business from her sister.  She travels to Cangallo and Colca markets and buys cochineal and 'tara' which she takes home, dries and sells to traders.

Gloria likes her community bank meetings because she learns a lot from the training sessions which their advisor provides on business, family and marriage topics.  Gloria's dream is to be able to get together enough capital to buy a knitting machine so that she can make sweaters and sell them.

loans.use: To buy cochineal and 'tara'

loans.name: Jenny Fernanda

texts.es: Jenny R. P. es una joven de 25 años que aprendió de su madre a ser independiente y a ser capaz de generar ingresos para si misma y para su crecimiento personal;  su ejemplo  fue el impulso que Jenny recibió durante su infancia,  para que en el año 2008, iniciara una forma de ganar dinero y ser autosuficiente, emprendiendo negocios que su capacidad observadora le permite visualizar como rentables; es así como  vende artesanías que produce en su propio  taller como mochilas y bolsos, que en la actualidad  exhibe en su miscelánea en su propia casa,  a la cual ha agregado gradualmente otros productos como calzado, repuestos y muchos artículos  que la gente necesita en su rutina diaria.  Así mismo Jenny R. vende arepas, carimañolas y otras frituras en la puerta de su casa diariamente, y también como realizó un curso de mantenimiento y reparación de celulares, aprovecha este conocimiento para ofrecer este mismo servicio, que le ha facilitado el saber negociar estos equipos, vender sus repuestos, carcasas, teclados, forros.  Los ingresos netos por este negocio  son de $550.000 COP, los cuales   representan un 30% de utilidad sobre la venta; con estos ingresos apoya  los gastos familiares y ha logrado pagar su educación como tecnóloga en mercadotecnia y que desea finalizar con mucho éxito. Su credikiva es el primer financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con él planea comprar un equipo de cómputo para mejorar y ampliar la gama de diseños y controlar mejor sus tareas diarias en sus negocios.
texts.en:
Jenny R. P. is a 25 year-old woman who learned from her mother how to be independent and make income for herself and for her personal growth.  It was her mother's example that Jenny observed during her childhood that spurred her, in 2008, to start earning her own money and become self-sufficient, starting businesses that her observant nature allowed her to see as profitable.

Jenny started out selling handicrafts that she produces in her own workshop such as backpacks and bags.  She currently displays her products in the general store she has in her own home.  She has gradually added other products such as footwear, spare parts and many articles that people need in their daily lives.

Jenny also sells 'arepas' (corn pancakes), 'carimañolas' (traditional Colombian fritters stuffed with cheese and meat and fried) and other fried food from the door of her home every day.  She has also taken a course on servicing and fixing cell phones and taken advantage of the knowledge she gained to start offering this service too.  She knows how to do business with these items and sell spare parts, cases, keyboards and covers for them.  Jenny's net profits for this business are 550,000 Colombian pesos which represent a 30% sales profit.  She uses her profits to support her family's expenses and has managed to pay for her education as a marketing technologist.  She hopes to finish this course successfully.

Jenny's Kiva loan is her first loan with Fundación Santo Domingo.  She plans to use it to buy a computer so that she can improve and expand her range of designs and better control her daily tasks in her businesses.

loans.use: To buy a computer so that she can improve and expand her range of designs and better control her daily tasks in her businesses

loans.name: Sara Esther

texts.es: La señora Sara González V. es una emprendedora mujer que desde hace 12 años se dedica a vender mercancía por catálogo en Barranquilla. Vive en un pequeño apartamento al norte de la ciudad en compañía de su único hijo varón, que es mayor de edad y está próximo a casarse. La usuaria ha logrado consolidar una buena clientela que desde años tras año crece. Recientemente fue ascendida a la categoría de “lider” por el volumen de venta y el número de nuevos vendedores que ha vinculado a la empresa. Ella bonifica por las ventas que realicen sus recomendados. Las ventas promedios mensuales de la señora Sara son de $ 1.200.000, su margen promedio de utilidad es del 35%, aunque en ocasiones aumenta cuando aprovecha las promociones del mes y compra grandes cantidades de artículos con descuentos que superan el 50%. Este es el cuarto crédito que la usuaria tramita con la Fundación y su primer Credikiva. Planea invertirlo en la compra de colonias, perfumes, cosméticos, ropa deportiva y accesorios para damas. Siempre se ha distinguido por su puntualidad en los pagos y su disposición a participar de manera entusiasta en todos los eventos a los que se les invita. La señora Sara, además de comerciante, es estilista de belleza y suele aprovechar las visitas a sus clientas para ofrecerle sus servicios. Con la proximidad de la temporada de fin de año las ventas y los pedidos se han incrementado considerablemente. La usuaria sueña con abrir al público un pequeño almacén en el cual pueda ofrecer todos sus productos, confía en que el próximo año pueda lograr hacer realidad ese proyecto.
texts.en:
Mrs Sara González V. is an enterprising woman who has been selling merchandise through catalogs in Barranquilla for 12 years.  She lives in a small apartment in the north of the city with her only son who is grown up and about to get married.  Sara has managed to establish a good client base which has been growing over the years.  She recently reached the category of 'leader' because of her sales volume and the number of new salespeople that she has introduced to the business.  She gets a discount for the sales that the people she has recommended make.

Sara's average monthly sales total 1,200,000 pesos.  Her average profit margin is 35% although it sometimes increases when she takes advantage of monthly promotions and buys larger quantities of articles with discounts that exceed 50%.

This is Sara's fourth loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and her first Kiva loan.  She plans to invest the money in buying aftershave, perfume, cosmetics, sports clothes and ladies' accessories.  She has always stood out for her punctuality in making her repayments and her willingness to participate enthusiastically in all the events to which she is invited.
