She has requested 30,000 Kes to buy clothes.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Kision

texts.en: Kision is a thirty-one-year-old married man with five children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in a retail shop business for two and a half years,  and this has helped him to educate his children. His business dream is to own a wholesale shop in the next four years. Kision needs the loan to buy sugar, salt, soap and sodas for sale.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap, salt and sodas

loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Ben is a thirty-seven-year-old married man with four children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been operating a taxi business for five years. He saved capital from his previous employment and bought a vehicle, and his hardship is competition. His vision is to buy a bigger motor vehicle and educate his children. Ben needs the loan to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for his business

loans.name: Koey

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Koey O., age 37, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns her living raising pigs. She has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. She is married with three children who are public school. She has a life partner in her husband who earns an income by selling firewood in his community. Besides his job, her husband often helps her in raising pigs.
 
Presently, she and her husband are building a new house to live in but her savings are insufficient for this project. So Koey O. is seeking a loan from Kiva to use to build her new house so she can have a new house soon to live in.

loans.use: To build her new house

loans.name: Peluce

texts.en:
Peluce is a forty-eight-year-old widow with eight children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been in commercial housing for ten years, a business which she inherited from her  late husband, who started with sugar cane selling then had a retail shop and saved money and bought land. However, her hardship is tenants who delay paying rent. Her vision is to build another commercial building and educate her children.

Peluce needs the loan to renovate a commercial building.

loans.use: Renovating commercial building

loans.name: Manweri

texts.en:
Manweri is a thirty-five-year-old married man with four children .He lives in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He is a cattle trader.

Manweri wants to increase his cattle herd from 6 animals to 15 animals. He also wants to  educate his children and build a permanent house. He wants a loan to purchase cattle for resale.

loans.use: Purchase cattle for resale

loans.name: Jumakan

texts.en:
Jumakan S. is a 52-year-old farmer and has seven grown children. She lives with her family in the north of Kyrgyzstan, in Kyzyl-Tuu village. 

Jumakan is engaged in cattle breeding and cultivation of kidney beans and perennial herbs, which she started with the initial capital of 5,500 KGS.    

Being a persistent person, Jumakan works hard and was able to enlarge her herd of livestock to one horse, one milch cow, and 15 sheep and earns about 8,000 KGS monthly.  Her tireless activity led Jumakan to obtain two loans from Bai Tushum and Partners to purchase livestock, loans which were repaid without any delays. 

Jumakan plans to use this loan of 50,000 KGS to expand her herd of cows and to purchase mineral fertilizers to fertilize land that will lead to  an increased harvest and top-quality products. With future revenue, Jumakan plans to purchase a good fence for her house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is a single lady who operates Gladtech Computers, where she sells computers and computer accessories. Her business is just a year old and she has one employee. Gladys hopes to expand her business and improve her living standard in five years' time. She has requested 20,000 KES to buy computer accessories.

loans.use: To buy computer accessories

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en: Mathew is a 39-year-old married man with three children who are in school. Through his barber shop business, he is able to educate his children. He started the business one year ago but was previously employed in a plastic manufacturing industry. As a member of Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to save his money and has gained business skills. He has requested 20,000 KES to buy shaving machines.

loans.use: To buy shaving machines

loans.name: Gulbaira Joldoshova's Group

texts.en:
Gulbaira J. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Toktogul. Gulbaira is 43 and married. Her husband works as a school teacher. Together, they bring up a daughter and a son, both of whom are at school. Three years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 KGS, the family started to breed cattle. Reselling cattle after fattening, they earn 10,000 KGS per month. This profit has made it possible for them to purchase furniture and improve the family’s living conditions. With this loan, Gulbaira wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she wants to give her children a good education. 

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane M., 42, is a single lady. She has been in the salon business for 12 years, where she manages to raise a profit of 16,000 KES monthly. The fact that she has been in the business for a long time has made her gather enough expertise which enables her to win and maintain old clients thus making her successful.

She has applied for a loan of 80,000 KES, which she intends to use to buy enough stock for the salon work. Her purchases will include cosmetics, chemicals, and some equipment like hair dryers so that she can improve the services she offers to her clients.

Jane plans to use the anticipated profits to run a beauty shop alongside the salon. This being her third loan, after successfully repaying the previous loans, indicates that she is doing well. She hopes and dreams to own a premises in the future.

loans.use: To purchase salon equipment

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. is 40 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has four children. None of her children are currently in school.
For over ten years, Rose has run a business selling suitcases. She also sells shoes and has rentals. To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase suitcases. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Rose hopes to own another business.

loans.use: To purchase suitcases for resale

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy N. is 29 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the last five years, Teddy has run a salon business. She also sells wholesale clothes.
To help expand her business, Teddy has requested a loan of 1,700,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more hair oil. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Teddy hopes to generate greater profits and be able to pay for school fees. In the future, Teddy hopes to own a car.

loans.use: To buy more hair oil

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Pauline N. est commerçante.  Elle a 43 ans, elle est veuve, et elle a 8 enfants entre 8 ans et 23 ans.  Elle a une éducation primaire, et tous ses enfants vont à l’école.  Elle était née à Congo (DRC), mais maintenant elle habite à Nyabugogo à Rwanda.  Elle va utiliser son prêt pour acheter 50 sacs de pommes de terre.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargner, et prendre beaucoup de prêts pour être indépendante chez elle.  Elle voudrait avoir un dépôt de pommes de terre, et aussi ajouter les bananes dans son commerce.  Pour sa famille, elle voudrait acheter une maison d’habitation.
texts.en: Pauline N. is a merchant. She is 43 years old, a widow, and the mother of eight, ranging from 8 to 23 years of age.. She has finished primary school, and all her children study. She was born in Congo (Democratic Republic of Congo), but now she lives in Nyabugogo in Rwanda. She is going to use her loan to purchase 50 bags of potatoes. Her strategy for growing her business is to save money and to keep taking out loans in order to be self-sufficient. She would like to have a warehouse for potatoes, and also to add bananas to her inventory  For her family, she would like to buy a house to live in.

loans.use: Purchasing 50 bags of potatoes

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina N. is 36 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children.  Both of her children are currently in school.  Amina has a shop selling suitcases, which she has had for 7 years.         

To help expand her business, Amina has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and stock more cases.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Amina hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Amina hopes to own another business.

loans.use: stock more cases.

loans.name: Joseph Olum

texts.en:
Joseph N. is 35 years old and is married to Mary. They have six children, with the eldest being 14 years old. They live in Kondele in Kisumu city.

Joseph is in the business of selling second hand clothes and has been doing it for 10 years. He is applying for his first loan from Kadet Ltd after being introduced by a friend who has benefited from the loans before. Joseph intends to use the money to buy five bales of clothes to add to his stock. The profits made from his business will be used for the family’s needs and also to pay school fees for his children.

His dream is to diversify into the transport business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes to add to his stock

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua A. sells plastic bowls at Abura. She has received junior high level of education. Ekua has been selling plastic bowls for three years. She uses the income she generates from her sales to take care of herself. Demand for her goods is increasing and she is requesting the loan to expand her business. She will use the loan to buy other plastic products requested by her customers.  She plans to reinvest her additional income.

loans.use: expand her plastic goods business

loans.name: Peter  Mugo

texts.en:
Peter has been operating a general store in Naivasha town for the last three years. He is a 25-year-old single man.

He was originally introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his third loan. He paid his previous loan of 26,000 KES in full and in good time. He plans to use the loan for increasing the inventory in his shop due to the high demand of commodities during the festive season.

In the future he hopes to expand his business to a wholesale shop and to be able to serve more customers in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To add more inventory to his shop

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba M. sells cloth and materials at Abura by moving from one area to another on foot. Araba has no educational background. She is divorced and has four children. She is responsible for the well-being of her family. Her loan will be used to buy additional cloth to expand her business. She hopes to build a shop for her business.

loans.use: buy additional cloth to expand her business

loans.name: Margaret Ene

texts.en:
Margaret has been raising livestock in Naivasha town for the last 12 years. She is a 42-year-old lady married to M. Ole Katieny. They have two children.

She was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in Naivasha. This will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy 25 sheep to raise and sell later, in oder to meet the high demand during the festive season.

In the future she hopes to be a major supplier of livestock to slaughter houses in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy 25 sheep

loans.name: Kang

texts.en:
Kang R., age 43, is a mother blessed with four children, all four of whom are single. Two of her children are employed in various jobs, and they also share their salary to help cover the family’s needs with her. Kang R. currently generates an income of approximately $2 per day by selling Khmer cake in her village. 

Kang R. has a life partner in her husband who sells beds in Kompong Tom Province and earns a profit on average of $3 per day. Kang R. said that the main income for her family comes from her husband’s business, and his business is running well step by step. 

So Kang R.’s husband wants to add more funds as  working capital to buy wood for making beds to sell. This is the reason why Kang R. is applying for a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: To buy wood to make beds to sell

loans.name: Auntie Monica

texts.en: Auntie Monica M. is married and has five dependents. Monica sells rice, canned tomatoes, cooking oil and other items at Abura, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a security man at the University of Cape Coast. She uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase more rice, cooking oil and other items to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Monica plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more rice, cooking oil and other items

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr: Odette N. est commerçante.  Elle a 41 ans, elle est veuve, et elle a 8 enfants entre 12 ans et 29 ans.  Elle a une éducation primaire, et tous ses enfants vont à l’école.  Elle était née à Congo (DRC), mais maintenant elle habite a Nyabugogo a Rwanda.  Elle va utiliser son prêt pour acheter de 30 sacs de pommes de terre.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargner, et augmenter le marché clientèle.  Elle voudrait arriver à vendre 100 sacs de pommes de terre dans une semaine.  Pour sa famille, elle voudrait bien élever ses enfants, et payer le minerval  et matériels scolaires pour ses enfants.
texts.en: Odette N. is a merchant. She is 41 years old, a widow, and the mother of eight children, from 12 to 29 years of age. She has finished primary school, and all her children go to school. She was born in Congo (Democratic Republic of Congo), but now she lives in Nyabugogo in Rwanda. She is going to use her loan to purchase 30 bags of potatoes. Her strategy for growing her business is to save money and to expand her customer base. She would like to be able to sell 100 bags of potatoes per week eventually. For her family, she would like to raise her children well and be able to provide for their tuition and school supplies.

loans.use: Purchasing 30 bags of potatoes

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed S. is 44 years old and lives in the town of Abaita in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  He is married and has one child. His child is currently in school.  Ahmed has a hardware business, which he has had for less than one year.  He also owns rental houses  

To help expand his business, Ahmed has requested a loan of 1,600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more hardware items.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Ahmed hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Ahmed hopes to expand his business further.

loans.use: more hardware items to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama M. smokes fish for sale. She also sells 'kenkey' (fermented corn dough) and fried fish at Abura. She is married and takes care of six dependents. Her husband works as security personnel. 

Ama has been in this business for some time now. She assists her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to fry for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her dependents.

loans.use: buy more fresh fish to fry for sale

loans.name: Zipporah Kamene

texts.en:
Zipporah K. is 21 years old, single, and the mother of one child. She owns a retail shop in Mandove in Mwingi town where she sells cooking fat, margarine, maize, mung beans, and rice.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. She had never borrowed from an MFI until she came to KADET LTD. This is her second loan. She repaid her first loan without difficulty. Zipporah plans to add more inventory of maize, mung beans, rice, and sugar. In the future, she hopes to buy a piece of land and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase maize, mung beans, rice, and sugar

loans.name: Nurjan's Group

texts.en:
Nurjan B., 47, is a resident of Kerben, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is the leader of this group. Her husband works as a driver at the hospital. Nurjan has a son; he is twelve and studies at school. Three years ago with the initial investment of 11,500 soms, the family started to breed livestock. Reselling livestock after fattening, they make 7200 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, Nurjan wants to purchase more livestock for breeding.  In the future the family plans to expand the business further and improve their living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more livestock

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en:
Godwin L. is 45 years old and lives in the town of Abaita in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  He is married and has 6 children.  Three of his children are currently in school.  Godwin has a sugar cane plantation, which he has had for over 10 years.  He also owns rental houses  

To help expand his business, Godwin has requested a loan of 1.700.000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more farm materials.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Godwin hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Godwin hopes to expand his business further.

loans.use: more farm materials

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa K. sells 'Fante kenkey' at Abura. 'Fante kenkey' is a popular Ghanaian dish made from corn. It is very common in the Western and  Central Region of Ghana. She is married and takes care of six dependents. Her husband is into farming. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more maize for 'kenkey'. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

In this photo, Adjoa is taking out the cooked 'kenkey' (wrapped in banana leaves) from her cooking pot.

loans.use: buy more maize for 'kenkey'

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to build up her business

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en: Fadi is a 36-year-old married man and father of two. He has run a snack bar/restaurant in Tyre for 18 years. Fadi is requesting a second loan from Al Majmoua to get a new car, necessary when buying food stuffs for his restaurant from the market. His previous loan had a good effect on his business. Fadi works hard to provide a secure living for his family and provide then with everything they need. His clients say that the quality of food he provides is perfect, and recommend others to try. Fadi hopes to expand his business and open a big restaurant in the future.

loans.use: To get a car for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sheep and animal feed

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en: Prossy M. is 34 years old and lives in the town of Kajjansi in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has five children all of them in school.  Prossy has had a business selling shoes for 10 years. To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 1,700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more shoes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits to buy food and, in the future, expand her business.

loans.use: buy more shoes.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey S. lives in Kompong Tom Province and makes a living raising pigs behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. Mrs. Srey S. has three children, two of whom work with her raising pigs. Her husband is a fisherman who uses an old motorbike to get his fish to the busy market to sell. Unluckily, his old motorbike is broken so Mrs. Srey S. will use her loan to purchase a used motorcycle to replace the broken one, and the remaining cash to buy fishing tools.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle (to replace a broken one) and fishing tools.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David K. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kajjansi in the Kampala west region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, four of them in school. David has had a business making bricks for six years.         

To help expand his business, David has requested a loan of 1,700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase more materials. With the help of this loan, David hopes to generate greater profits to buy food. In the future, he hopes to own another business.

loans.use: more brick-building materials

loans.name: Damira's Group

texts.en:
Damira J. is 35 years old, married, and has three children, all of whom attend school.  She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, the family breeds livestock animals, which Damira and her husband have been doing since 1996.  Reselling livestock animals after fattening, they earn 3,600 soms a month. Damira applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase coal for winter. In the future she wants to improve the family’s living conditions and provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan.  MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.  If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase coal for winter

loans.name: Stephania

texts.en:
Stephania N. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kajjansi in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has five children.  Four of her children are currently in school.  Stephania has a retail shop, which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Stephania has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase sugar and beans.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Stephania hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Stephania hopes to expand the business

loans.use: sugar, beans

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new shop and make his business bigger

loans.name: Aishekul's Group

texts.en:
Aishekul A. is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan).  Aishekul, 51, is the leader of this group. She is married and has five children.  The youngest daughter is still at school and the other children are working. 

In order to earn money, Aishekul and her husband raise cattle. They have been doing it for sixteen years. Reselling cattle after fattening they earn 8300 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, Aishekul wants to purchase a cow in order to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to see her children get wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Lim C. is a rural villager of 24 years old, who lives in Kompong Tom Province. Here, she makes a living raising pigs in a pig stall located near her house on her land. She raises pigs in order to raise their offspring and for selling. Since the beginning of 2008 until the present, she has raised pigs. Her husband is a fisherman in their community. 

Presently, Lim C. faces difficulties with her traveling needs because her existing motorcycle is broken down. Therefore, she would like to borrow some funds from Kiva to repair her broken motorbike and purchase fishing gear for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To repair her broken motorbike and purchase fishing gear for  her husband

loans.name: Mrs. Muong Sam Oeurn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Muong S. O. is the village bank president who has been selected by the nine members of this loA. group who will each use their portion of the loA. for different purposes. All the members who make up this village bank loA. are located in Prey Khla village, Takeo province. 

Mrs. Muong S. O. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow both rice and bananas on to sell to support her family while her husband is a laborer who earns a small salary to support his family, too. In the rice field, it is time to grow rice but she has little money for this purpose. To improve production, Mrs. Muong S. O. is asking for a loA. to do farming. She will use any remainder of the loA. to buy a bicycle for her children to ride to school. She is a mother of five children all of whom are studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is 55 years old and married to Florence, who is a farmer. They have been blessed with four children. Edward has been operating a food kiosk for the last three years and earns 21,000 KES per month.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. This is his first loan from KADET. His goal is to open a new branch of his food kiosk in Ngararisha; Limuru since he has many customers. This is a very large town.  

The business has been successful, as evidenced by the fact that he is planning to open a second branch. They are fortunate that his wife has also been in a position to help in meeting their expenses. He hopes and dreams of owning a big hotel in the future.

loans.use: To open a second kiosk

loans.name: Hakim

texts.en:
Hakim M. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala South region of Uganda.  He is single and has no children.  Hakim has a retail shop, which he has had for 5 years.         

To help expand his business, Hakim has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase sugar and beans.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Hakim hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Hakim hopes to own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: sugar and beans

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is a thirty-year-old single man with one child and rents a two-roomed house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the transport sector for two years with a challenge of motorcycle breakdown as a result of bad roads. His vision is to build his own house and buy two more motorcycles. Richard needs the loan to buy a motorcycle for his business.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase construction supplies and build a house

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a thirty-four-year-old single woman with two children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling second-hand clothes for the last three and a half years, however her hardships include damages to the clothing and poor sales during the rainy season. Her vision is business expansion and growth plus educating her children.

Margret needs the loan to buy second-hand clothes for resale.

loans.use: Buy second-hand clothing for resale

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Sok Heng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is comprised of fourteen people who have selected Mrs. Chan S. H. to be village bank president. They will use their loan amounts for various purposes in order to support their families located in Prey Khla village, Takeo province. 

Mrs. Chan S. H. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Aside from farming she makes thatch to sell. She tries to work hard but she can earn only a little money to support her family. To increase her income, Mrs. Chan S. H. is applying for a loan to buy some piglets to raise to start a new business. With the remainder of the loan she plans to buy a bicycle to use. 

She is a widow with five children, two of whom are employed in garment factories and the others are studying in the public school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and a bicycle for transport

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has six children, all of whom attend school.  She also takes care of her brothers.  Sarah has a business of selling used clothing. She has been in this business for six years, and she works seven days a week. Sarah sells her products at the market.  Sarah has requested for a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. The main business challenges for Sarah include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations are to start selling wholesale only and to build her own house. Sarah  lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en: Nelson is a forty-eight-year-old married man with seven children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the clothing business for fifteen years, His business has been expanding over time, however his challenges include high rent and trading license charges plus competition. His vision is to open a wholesale business and educate his children to higher institutions of learning.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell for the season

loans.name: Martin

texts.en: Martin is a thirty-four-year-old married man with six children and owns a house in Kasese. He has been selling sodas and beers for the last three years however the demand is greater than he can supply. His vision is to be a wholesaler and educate all his children. Martin needs the loan to buy sodas and beers to sell.

loans.use: To buy sodas and beers

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina N. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school.  Zaina has a business selling banana leaves. She has been in this business for ten years, and she works 7 days out of every week. 

Zaina sells her products at the market, wholesale and retail. Zaina has requested a loan of 300,000/= Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bundles of banana leaves.  She also generates additional income through selling charcoal. The main business challenges for Zaina include seasonality and thieves. 

Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to build her own house. Zaina lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn’t have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bundles  of banana leaves

loans.name: Loice

texts.en: Loice is a thirty-three-year-old married female with six children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She started with a small stall in the market but now has had a shop for clothes for the last fifteen years, however, her challenge is lack of enough capital. Her vision is to buy more clothes and educate her children up to university level. Loice needs the loan to buy clothes.

loans.use: Buying clothes for sale

loans.name: Bakamwegha

texts.en: Bakamwegha is a thirty-eight-year-old married man with three children and rents a house in Kasese. He has been buying and selling passion fruit for the last seven years, however he has a challenge of long distances and the hilly landscape. His vision is to build his own house and open up a grocery in Kampala city. Bakamwegha intends to use the loan to buy passion fruit for resale.

loans.use: To buy passion fruit

loans.name: Tojiddin

texts.en:
Tojiddin T. is 36 years old.  He lives in Isfara town. Tojiddin processes and sells dried fruits in the central local market. Together with the help of his brothers who are currently in Russia, he also sells his products in Russia. He is experienced in the business of making dried fruits. He purchases dried fruits from local farmers as a wholesale and after processing sells them to his customers. Because he buys his goods wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices. He offers a wide assortment of goods for clients of different means. All this allows Tojiddin to make his business successful, which provides a stable income for his family. Currently, he needs a loan of $3,000 loan to buy supplies so he can continue to offer a good product to his customers. Tojiddin expresses his gratitude for everyone supporting him.     


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions. Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for dried fruit

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a thirty-two-year-old married woman with two children and owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling maize and cassava flour for the last two years and has managed to buy a motorcycle for 'boda-boda' (motorcycle transport) business. Her hardships are the bad weather and poor roads for transporting the flour. Her vision is to have another business. Grace needs the loan to buy maize and cassava flour for sale.

loans.use: To buy maize and cassava flour

loans.name: Hasifa

texts.en:
Hasifa N. lives in the Kasubi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her brother and his daughter). 

Hasifa has a farm produce sales business. She has been in this business for two years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Hasifa sells her products at the market, retail.  Hasifa has requested a loan of 300,000/= Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of beans and groundnuts.  

The main business challenges for Hasifa include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to build her own house. Hasifa lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn’t have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees, food, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of beans and groundnuts

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
Munira is married with three children. She lives in Isfara with her family and runs her business selling blankets, kerchiefs and towels in the central market. She launched her enterprise 6 years ago. Munira has rich experience working in this business. The first time she applied to IMON International for financial assistance was 6 years ago. Ever since, her business has expanded, and she gained a reputation as an entrepreneur of integrity and great potential. 

Munira has consistent credit history in IMON International. We believe her positive standing and strong determination to achieve even higher goals will help her succeed and repay her loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods to expand the range of merchandise

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles, a 60-year-old married father of two children, lives in Fort Portal Uganda in the home he owns. His 17 years as an agriculturalist have provided him with sufficient income to buy land and send his children to school. Charles' business dream is to specialize and become a commercial farmer supplying large quantities of produce in a sustainable manner.

Now requesting a loan to pay for the labor to clear his farmland and to buy seeds for planting, he hopes to eventually set up businesses for his children.

loans.use: To pay labor costs to clear his farmland and to buy seeds for planting.

loans.name: Anush

texts.en:
Anush M. lives in Ijevan city. She is married with three children. 
She has run her own business for about 30 years. She sews to order and alters ready-made clothes. She sews from material which brings her clients and from material she buys herself. 
Anush sews clothes, leathers, bed linen and curtains. Due to this variety, she has many clients.    
Anush has supported her family with income from the business, paid for her children's educations, organized her elder daughter’s wedding and repaired her apartment. 
Anush is asking for a 600,000 Armenian drams loan to buy a new sewing machine and materials for her business.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine and sewing materials

loans.name: Joselyne

texts.en: Joselyne is 34 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of three and 12. Joselyne works as a tailor with her husband and she has been doing so for 10 years. She has requested this loan to buy more threads and material for making garments. She hopes to buy land with the profits. She would like to have more sewing machines in the future.

loans.use: To buy more threads and material

loans.name: Beathe

texts.en: Beathe is 33 years old, married, and has three children, one of who attends school. Her husband works as a mason. Beathe sells a variety of items in her shop. She has been in this business for seven months. She is requesting a loan to buy clothes and she believes that the profits will be re-invested for the growth of her business. She hopes to have a big shop in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes

loans.name: Floride

texts.en:
Floride is 30 years old. She is married and has two children who are between four and seven years old. One of her children goes to school and her husband works as a businessman. Floride sells potatoes and she has been selling these potatoes for two years. 

She has requested this loan to buy more potatoes to sell and the profits from this business will be used to renovate her house. She dreams of becoming a supplier of potatoes in the future.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes to sell

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
Zafar Z.  is married and has four children. With the faith that his children would go to school to get ahead, he started a business of processing and selling dried apricots so that he could earn enough money to pay for their schooling. He started this business 20 years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business and is able to expand his clientele day by day. Zafar is requesting a loan for 7,500 Somoni to purchase dried apricots to process and sell.

loans.use: To purchase dried apricots

loans.name: Nihad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old. He is married and has one child. He is the only provider for his family.

Nihad opened his own barber shop after having a long experience in this field. He is well known and has a good reputation in his local area.

He is requesting a $2400 loan to renovate his shop. He is planning to grow bigger and improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: Renovate his shop

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean De Dieu is 29 years old and single. Currently, he sells a variety of items in his shop such as cooking oil, sweets, soaps and sandals. He wants to add a line of clothes to his shop with the loan he has requested. The profits arising from this loan will strengthen his business and help him grow his boutique.

Jean dreams of buying a motor vehicle in the future to help his business activities in terms of transportation.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Alimahmadjon

texts.en:
Alimahmadjon K. is a hardworking person, and he makes an effort to give his family the best. He decided to stay in his homeland so that he could develop it, and now he carries out his everyday chores with a lot of love and affection as he cultivates the land and feeds his animals.

With experience gained over four years in the purchase and sale of cattle Alimahmadjon has been able to bring stability to his family. He would now like to purchase more cattle to create more income for his large family. For this reason he is requesting a loan of 7500 TJS. Alimahmadjon thanks you very much.

More about Tajikistan:

Tajikistan is known for its rich place in history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the farthest reach of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve their agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

About IMON International:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients have access to reasonable financial services. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a tent for his work

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.en:
Bakhtiyor is married and has three children. He has a small store where he sells blankets, towels and other merchandise. Bakhtiyor has been in this business for 15 years. He runs it with his wife who encouraged him to start the business and is very supportive. Bakhtiyor is requesting a loan of $3000 to purchase more goods. This business has its high season now. Bakhtiyor believes that opening second location will give him an advantage over his competitors and provide his family with more profit in the coming New Year holidays.

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing to increase the variety of goods in the store.

loans.name: Baker

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old. He is married and has one child. He is the only provider for his family.

In 2007, Baker opened his own barber shop after having a long experience working in this field. He is becoming well known and has a good reputation in his local area.

He is requesting a $1800 loan to advertise and renovate his shop and to buy an air conditioner. He is aiming to grow bigger to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: Advertise and renovate his shop

loans.name: Yusufbek

texts.en:
M. Yusufbek is 39 years-old.  He is married with three children. During the last five years, Yusufbek is providing transportation services. He generally works in his region only. At the same time, together with the help of his wife and eldest son, he raises cattle in his house which gives additional income for his family. Currently, Yusufbek’s truck needs repair and for this reason he is requesting a loan of 12000 Somoni.  With a portion of the loan he will also buy additional cattle for his business. Yusufbek promises to pay the loan in time and thanks anyone for their support.

loans.use: To repair his microbus and purchase young cattle.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
W. Florence lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children all of whom are in school..  She also takes care of her father.   

Florence has a business selling second hand clothes .She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days out of every week.  Florence sells her products from home.    Florence has requested a loan of 300000/= Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO.  She will use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She also generates additional income through selling soda, passion juice soda and mineral water. The main business challenges for Florence include the ever increasing prices of clothes and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and to start importing clothes herself. 

Florence lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity but doesn’t have access to  piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees, food and medications.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes.

loans.name: Saidhamza

texts.en:
“Responsible fatherhood” is a term that has been converted into concrete fact in Saidhamza’s life. He has always responded satisfactorily to his role as provider for his six children, for whom he cares with much love, in the company of his wife, who is always supportive of him. Saidhamza works in agricultural activities and has some cattle. He cultivates wheat, and potatoes and other vegetables depending on the season. At the moment, he is working intensively at his agricultural activities and taking care of his fields. His wife is helping take care of the cows and also sells their milk. They do all this hard work because they want to give an education to each of their children. They would also like to open a small business some day but, until then, they will continue working in their fields. To do this, Saidhamza is requesting a loan of $2200 USD to buy seeds, mineral fertilizers and young cattle. Let’s support Saidhamza in his continuous efforts to provide for the wellbeing of his family.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and young cattle.

loans.name: Saiyohatdin

texts.en:
Saiyohatdin is married and the father of three children. He is a farmer. Together with his wife they are engaged in the business of raising and selling cattle and also grow wheat and potatoes. He is hopeful of making progress in his business and providing for his family's needs. For that reason, he wants to invest in his production, expand his crop fields and improve the quality of his products. Saiyohatdin knows that if he takes care of his land and works diligently he will reap excellent products that will have a better reception in the marketplace. The request Saiyohatdin makes is to purchase seed, fertilizer and young cattle.

loans.use: Purchasing seed, fertilizer and young cattle

loans.name: Afaf

texts.en: Afaf is a 31 years old married woman, mother of two kids and owner of a household appliances shop, where she also sells accessories and perfumes. Afaf has been in business for five years. Afaf helps her husband in their income and seeks perfection in her work. Afaf is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to increase her inventory of household appliances, because there have been a lot of requests these days. Afaf hopes to open new branches in the future.

loans.use: Purchase inventory of household appliances for sale

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en: Gorret N. lives in the Namungoona neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of her father. Gorret has a business of tailoring. She has been in this business for five years and she works 7 days out of every week. Gorret sells her products at the market, by means of retail.  Gorret has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of clothing materials. She also generates additional income through selling African attire (Bitengi). The main business challenges for Gorret include defaulters and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on wholesale only and also to own a tailoring school. Gorret lives in a home that she owns she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of clothing materials

loans.name: Rafiki Group

texts.fr: Katsuva M. est entrepreneur, âgée de 56 ans, veuve, mère de 6 enfants.  Son mari est décédé depuis plus de 7 ans.  Elle est vendeuse du riz.  Elle  commença son business  avec  son fonds propre reçu d’un membre de famille, il ya 7 ans qu’elle fait cette activité. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ en 2007. Elle installe ses marchandises dans un dépôt agricole à Birere centre. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  1 sac de riz de 100 kg et 1 sac de haricot. En plus, elle ambitionne réaliser un fonds pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en volume. En outre, elle compte acheter une seconde parcelle d’héritage à ses enfants.  La cliente Katsuva M. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Rafiki est constitué de 25 membres.
texts.en: Katsuva M. is a 56-year old entrepreneur, 56 years old, a widow and the mother of six. Her husband passed away over seven years ago. She sells rice. She launched her business with her own starting capital received from a relative. She has been in this business for seven years. At a later point, in 2007, she obtained a loan of 50$ from IMF in Hekima. She keeps her merchandise in an agricultural depot in the cener of Birere. This new loan will allow her to purchase one 100-kg [220 lbs] bag of rice and one bag of green beans. In addition, her goal is to expand her sales volume. She also would like to purchase a second plot of land which would be her children’s inheritance. As a client of Hekima, Katsuva M. appreciates its work to assist the poor who don’t have access to the traditional banking system. The Rafiki group consists of 25 members.

loans.use: Purchasing one 100-kg bag of rice and one bag of green beans

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Gyulnara

texts.en:
Gyulnara A. was born in 1967 in Ijevan city. She is married and has a school aged son. 
Gyulnara is a pharmacist, but since 1987, she has rented a stall where she manages her own business. Her business consists of selling clothes, underclothes, bedclothes and towels. She says children's clothes are always in popular demand, so she makes an emphasis on it at her business. 
The profits from the sales allow her to take care of the needs of her family and support her trade. 
Before the New Year’s holiday, Gyulnara wants to increase her shop’s assortment and therefore requests a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy winter clothes for resale.

loans.use: To buy winter clothes for resale

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
Nasiba is married with two children. She runs a small business selling clothing for children. Nasiba has a perfect credit history with IMON International. She has promptly repaid all loans without any delinquencies. Her neat vending place has a beautiful array of inventory, customer-friendly service and exceptional prices, which has led to the preeminent success of her business. Nasiba would like to get a loan of 7500 Somoni to re-stock her inventory. She is planning on increasing her supplies of clothing to attract more potential clients to her vending place. Nasiba believes her efforts and determination, in combination with financial support, will eventually help her fully achieve her potential, leading to increased income and success.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of new goods for selling in order to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Masikilizano Group

texts.fr: F. K. est entrepreneur, âgée de 34 ans, mariée, mère de 11 enfants.  Seulement 6 enfants  étudient  et les 5 autres n’étudient pas faute de moyens financiers. Son époux est chauffeur d’un privé.  Elle vend l’huile de palme.  Elle  commença son business  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son époux ayant une valeur de 30$. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$. Elle installe ses marchandises au marché sectoriel du quartier Ndosho. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  3 bidons d’huile de palme. En plus, elle ambitionne réaliser un fonds pour scolariser ses enfants. La cliente F. K. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Le groupe Masikilizano est constitué de 34 membres.
texts.en: F. K. is an entrepreneur who is 34 years old and the mother of 11 children. Only 6 of her children are in school, the others do not attend school for the lack of financial resources. Her husband is a private chauffeur. She sells palm oil. She started out her business with her own money, funds that were given to her by her husband totalling $30. Later she received her first loan from IMF Hekima in the amount of $50. She has her business in the market located in the Ndosho quarter. Her new loan will be used to purchase 3 barrels of palm oil. She hopes to raise enough money to send her kids to school. F. K. is grateful to the Hekima organization for their efforts to cater to the poor who are excluded from traditional banks. The group named Masikilizano is made up of 34 members.

loans.use: acheter 3 bidons d’huile de palme

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Zainura

texts.en:
Zainura is a widowed mother of two children. After the death of her husband, Zainura had to find ways to provide for herself and her two kids. For 17 years, she has had a small business selling clothing for children. It has now become the main source of income for her family. Zainura is a cheerful, hard-worker despite the difficulties she faces. She has received and repaid 18 loans from “IMON International” which has helped create stability for her business. Zainura is requesting a loan for 7500 Somoni for purchasing new goods. One of her long-term goals is to rent a second vending facility. In pursuit of her goal, Zainura plans to invest her extra profits into the expansion of her business. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase additional clothing for sale

loans.name: James

texts.en: James O. O. is married to a shopkeeper and they have five children aged between twelve years and five months old. James and his wife hope to give their children good education through the university level. His business is located at a market place in Kitengela. He has been selling items such as cookers, pans, metal boxes and others. He sells to the local people in wholesale. He has been in this business for four years now and has three employees. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he faces is that there are other people in the area in the same business as him so customers are spoilt for choice. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 45,000 to buy scrap metal to make more items to meet the demands of his customers. grow his business and become a market leader. He describes himself as wise and business minded.

loans.use: Purchase of scrap metal as raw material

loans.name: Sorbeh Turn Table Group

texts.en:
Rugiatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Rugiatu was born in Makeni city, about forty years ago. She is married to a contractor and the couple has four children. 

Rugiatu sells market food – rice, onions, tomatoes, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), pepper, groundnuts, fish, etc. She has been a businesswoman for twenty-five years now. With her share of this loan, Rugiatu is going to expand her business by buying the above mentioned items in large quantity to add to her current ones.

loans.use: Purchase inventory in large quantities for sale

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys B. lives in the Kalerwe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children whom are in school.  She also takes care of her father. Gladys has a tailoring business. She has been in this business for five years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Gladys sells her products at the market, by means of retail.  Gladys has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of clothing material.The main business challenges for Gladys are defaulters and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to own a tailoring school. Gladys in a home that she owns she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of clothing materials

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose O. is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has one child, who is currently in school. For over ten years, Rose has run a business selling clothes.
To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and pay her child's school fees. In the future, Rose hopes to become a popular businesswoman.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Tanutsu Women Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Tanutsu Women” group. They are small scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Fanta S.. Fanta is age thirty-seven; she was born in Makeni city where she is currently residing together with her husband and three children. Fanta is a businesswoman who sells cloths. She has been in the business of buying and selling for six years now. With her share of this loan, she will, as usual travel to neighboring Guinea where she will buy bales of lace cloths and wax cloths to sell in Makeni.

loans.use: Purchase lace and wax cloths for sale

loans.name: Akil

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 45 years old. He is married and has three children. Two of his relatives also live at his place.

In 2004, Akil decided to open his own blacksmith workshop. Now he has good experience that has made him well-known in his region. Also Akil has an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a $2400 loan to renovate his workshop and install a roll shutter for his store. He plans to expand his business in the future.

loans.use: Renovate his workshop and install a roll shutter for his store

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 42 year-old married man and father of 5 kids living in Baalbeck. He has been working as a car mechanic (auto repair) for 28 years. Hasan is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time in order to start a new business for his wife. He wants to open a grocery store, since their financial situation needs a little push to fulfill their family’s needs. Hasan hopes this new step helps.

loans.use: Start a grocery store

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “In God We Trust” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are small businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva in order to seek for a loan of SLL 1,200,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Alpha K.. Alpha was born in the village of Sanda Gbanti Kamaranka, near Makeni about forty-two years ago. He is married and has five children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending schools.

Alpha sells used bags. He has had twenty-five years of experience in doing this business. He is requesting for this loan in order to buy more second-hand bags to add to his business.

loans.use: Buy more second-hand bags to add to his business.

loans.name: Enid

texts.en:
Enid T. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not currently in school. For the last seven years, Enid has run a business selling clothes. She is also a supplier of shower caps.
To help expand her business, Enid has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bridal materials. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Enid hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Enid hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: To purchase more bridal materials

loans.name: Hope Sisters Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone is very please to present to you members of the “Hope Sisters” group. These are small scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek for a loan of SLL 800,000.00 for each in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Fatu J. is the leader of this group. Fatu is fifty-five-year-old, married with six children. Fatu sells salt, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), soap, milk, cocoa, etc. She has been doing business for more than thirty years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items in large quantity to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buys salt, margi, soap, milk, cocoa, etc. in large quantity to add to her current stock for resale

loans.name: Jaseb

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 45 years old. He is married and the only provider for his wife and three children.

In 2008 Jaseb started his own business by opening his small food market. He provides a big variety of products. He is becoming well known in his local community and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $2100 loan to buy a small generator and redecorate his shop. He is planning to extend his shop and grow bigger in the future.

loans.use: Buy a small generator and redecorate his shop

loans.name: Hope To God Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Hope To God” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. 

Zainab C. is the leader of this group. Forty one year-old Zainab is married to a tailor and they have four children. Zainab has been a businesswoman for ten years now, selling shoes and clothes. With her share of this loan, Zainab is going to buy shoes and clothes at wholesale to add to her current stock. She will also use part of the loan to buy gallons of palm-oil and bags of rice for sale.

loans.use: Buys shoes, clothes, palm-oil and rice in large quantities for sale

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en: Sylvia B. lives in the Kamwokya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children whom are in school. She also takes care of her father. Sylvia has a business of selling shoes. She has been in this business for five years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Sylvia sells her products at the market, by means of retail.  Sylvia has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of second hand shoes. The main business challenges for Sylvia are defaulters and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to build her own house. Sylvialives in a home that she rents, she doesn’t have access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, food and medication.

loans.use: To buy second-hand shoes for sale

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith M. is married with one nine year-old child. Her husband is an employee of The Kenya Power and Lighting Company. They hope to enable their child to reach the university level. Her business is located at busy market place called Fedha and she is served by the Kitengela branch. She owns a beauty shop in which she sells such things as weaves, braids, shampoo, hair oil, hair conditioner, nail polish, etc. She sells to saloonists, beauticians and local customers. She has been doing this business for four years now and has one employee. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is that there are other people in the area doing the same business as hers so customers are spoilt for choice. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 70,000 to buy more cosmetics to increase her stock and to renovate other rental houses she owns. She hopes to grow her business and open more beauty shops in other towns. She describes herself as kind, honest, business minded and opportunistic.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet N. is 39 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school.
For the last six years, Juliet has run a business selling clothes. To help expand her business, Juliet has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Juliet hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Juliet hopes to own a shop of her own.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Musaya Musyoki

texts.en:
Musaya is 54 years old and married to Musyoki, who contributes to the family's income. She owns a retail shop where she sells assorted cereals, flour, soaps, and detergent. She has been in this business for about eleven years and earns an income of about 4,400 KES per month.

She has a very good history with Kadet. This is her third loan. She has successfully repaid the previous two loans. With this loan, she intends to buy more inventory such as mung beans, maize, and beans. She hopes to own a wholesale store in the future.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her store

loans.name: Taalaybek

texts.en:
Taalaybek S. is a 47 years-old farmer. He lives in a happy marriage with his wife Indira and has three children. His eldest son is a student and the others are schoolchildren. 

Taalaybek has engaged in cattle breeding for 10 years and has a farm with four milk cows, whose milk he sells to the local diary farm. With the revenues from these activities, he was able to pay for education for his son and make income for living. 

Taalaybek plans to use the loan of 80,000 KGS to broaden his farm through buying four bull calves for fattening and reselling and forage for the cattle. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business and makes every effort to provide his family with prosperous future.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Kiiza

texts.en: Kiiza is a thirty one year-old married male with five children and owns a house in Kasese. He has been dealing in produce for the last ten years. Business hardships he face include price fluctuations, poor seasons and pests. His vision is to be a chief supplier for institutions around the area plus to have a well educated family. Kiiza needs the loan to buy beans and maize for sale.

loans.use: To buy beans and maize for sale

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a thirty year-old married female with four children and owns a house in Kasese. She has been selling clothes and shoes for the last five years. She started the business with five hundred shillings of capital and has expanded to capital of three million shillings. However, she still does not have enough capital to meet customer demands. Her vision is to open up another shop. Margret needs the loan to buy additional clothes for sale.

loans.use: Buy new clothes and shoes for sale

loans.name: Nyakoojo

texts.en: Nyakoojo Geofrey is 27 years old and married with a child. He has no other dependants. He owns the home he lives in and his goal is to build a better, permanent house and be able to meet his family's needs. He has had a bodaboda (motorcycle transport) business for for eight years. He started by being a rider for some one else and, with money saved, bought his own motorcycle. He faces the challenge of poor roads and fuel-price fluctuations. In future he hopes to have many motorcycles. The loan is to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a motocycle

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en: Vincent O. O. is thirty five years old and married. His wife sells charcoal while Vincent is a blacksmith. He makes items such as cookers and also does pottery and ceramics. They have two children aged twelve years and ten who they hope to educate to university level. His business is in Kitengela, a busy area near a slaughter house. He has been selling his goods to retailers for three years and says that his business is profitable. His main challenge is scarcity of raw materials and competition from other businesses in the area which are similar to his. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. Vincent is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy scrap metal, clay and red ochre to make more items and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes some day to be a market leader in the industry. He describes himself as honest and business oriented.

loans.use: to buy scrap metal, clay, and red ochre

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy has a mixed farm in the town of Murang'a in central Kenya. She has been farming for the last seven years and employs four farmhands. Her mixed farm produces milk and horticultural products, which she sells to the local market. She also earns income from her small-scale farming of coffee.

Lucy is 33 years old and married with four school-aged children who all attend school.

She has requested this loan of 62,400 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help her educate her children without straining.
